title: The Jewish Cookbook review: A historical document up there with Claudia Roden's pioneering work
text:
To describe it simply as a “cookbook” is a disservice. The Jewish Cookbook (Phaidon, £35) is a tome, a historical document. Leah Koenig, a New-York-based food writer, has spent much of the past decade chronicling the stories and recipes that make up Jewish cuisine – which, of course, is as varied as the diasporic culture itself.

For me, it’s always been about pierogi, schnitzels, latkes and my grandmother’s walnut cake. For others, it could be a lamb tagine, a Turkish borek, a spicy Mexican chicken soup or an Ethiopian stew. This book explores all the cuisine has to offer – to my mind, it’s up there with Claudia Roden’s pioneering work.
